content.description: Start on the right side on the arete. crux is the first few move because it is very tricky on your feet
content.location: The north west corner of the boulder

content.description:
As it names implies, "Tiptoe" is a technical boulder problem that focuses a lot on balance and sure feet to get the send.  The crux is getting past the large chalked-up undercling - right hand to a good crimper, throwing left and pulling past the triangle-shaped sloper to a large bomber crimp that you can match on.  A high right foot definitely helps here (use the crimper you used a right hand on above the undercling).  Throw right to an awesome pinch, backstep your left foot, throw left to the large side-pull, and pull over the top leading with your right leg/foot.  This is just the sequence that works for me, as I am sure that there are multiple ways to send this problem.

This boulder feels almost slicker with each passing year!
content.location: Located left of the arete on House Boulder's West Face.  Use the tree next to "Speedball" to shimmy down.

content.description: The North face of the boulder. Start on two well chalked crimps about chest high. Be sure not to move too far left, using holds that are on for North East Arete (V2) are off!
Perfect classic route, start with right hand in a crimpy undercling and left hand in a chest high shallow pocket
content.location: the south side of the boulder

content.description: The south east corner of the boulder. look for obvious chalk marks. crux is first move. climb down the tree once you are on top of the bolder.
content.location: 20 feet off the side of the road... cant miss it

content.description:
Sit down start on the arete.  Climb the left side of the arete.  One of the better boulder problems on House Boulder.  Both variations share the same sit start, which is grabbing a good pinch (used to be a jug years ago) with your left hand and a flat sloping edge with your right.

By AF standards the left variation is a "soft" V5 - the crux is throwing up and far left for this positive yet small sloping knob.  The right variation felt a tad easier so I labeled it as a V4/5.  The arete is off - if it's on, then V3.  As always, feedback is welcome so that I posted the correct beta!
content.location: Sit start on the southeast arete - then out to the face - of House Boulder.  Use the tree next to Speedball to shimmy down.

content.description: the North west corner of the boulder, very fun bouldering here
content.protection: Crash pads, a rope and rappel gear can be nice to get down of the boulder

content.description: Start on the gaston just right of Speedball.  Head up and exit right to the arete.
Awkward start for feet, off a tricky gaston. Moves straight up to the top corner of the rock

The start is pretty much the same as the Slabbed Crimp (North Side) but you try to keep both hands in the Arete and climb straight up. Its a fun climb with some pretty good holds. You can also use a few of the crimps to the right to make it a little easier. Try to keep hand and feet as close to the arete as possible.

Goes straight up the tallest part of the east side of House Rock. Crux is a tricky mantel starting in an obvious dish on the slab. I've seen shorter people  stand on a folded pad (or a rock) to get high enough to start (up to you if that's cheating). Don't fall topping out or else you'll probably land on the rock before your pad. Avoid the urge to go to the left or use the arete to the right, that's off route.
content.protection: Bouldering pad, but it won't do ya a ton of good if you fall from up top cause you'll probably land on the rock.
content.location: Goes straight up the tallest part of the east side of House Rock. Starts in a dish towards right edge of the flat/slabby part of the rock.

content.description: Obvious line with kinda gross climbing. I’d be surprised if this hadn’t been done before, but it was listed as a project here so I figured I’d post it. SDS on an incut edge and bust left with a couple hard, scrunchy moves on slopers, finishing on East Face.
content.location: East face, obvious crimp start hold.

content.description: The East Face of the bolder. obvious chalk marks all over the place. A good heel hook is the key to this climb

Not sure if tiptoe right and this one are the same but its on rockclimbing.com anong with tiptoe right so im not sure what the difference between the two climbs is. Its definitely a V8. It has a fun sequence when you figure it out. The crux is the upper half of the climb, it involves lots of inward pressure and friction.
content.location:
South west arete, climb the south side of the arete.

The start I use is a crimp on the west side of the arete and a bad one finger sloper on the south side
